newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Anglo-Spanish consortium to explore Kazakh oil.
newsitem.headline: Anglo-Spanish consortium to explore Kazakh oil.

text.p: A consortium of Spain's Repsol oil firm and Britain's Enterprise Oil Plc signed a deal with Kazakhstan on Wednesday to explore its north-western Baiganinsk oil field, Repsol said in a statement.

"On July 9, 1997, a consortium comprised of Spanish company Repsol...and British company Enterprise Oil...signed a tax and royalty agreement for the exploration and production of oil in the Baiganinsk contract area with the Republic of Kazakhstan," said the statement.

Willy Hernandez, Repsol Exploracion Kazakhstan S.A. General Manager, told a news briefing prior to the signing at the former Soviet republic's energy and natural resources ministry that the consortium would invest $25 million in the first six year.
He said Repsol would invest 60 percent of the sum and Enterprise Oil the remaining 40 percent, in line with their shares in the consortium.

The contract area of some 10,000 square km in Kazakhstan's north-western Aktyubinsk region, which the consortium was awarded by the Kazakh government after a tender in 1993, "has a high potential", said Hernandez but gave no further detail.
But asked on the consortium's plans if oil is found in the region, he said: "We are interested not only in exploration but production." He said exploration works would start in September.

Kazakhstan, a vast steppeland Central Asian state five times the size of France and with a population of just 16.7 million people, has huge reserves of oil, and foreign investors have muscled their way into its energy sector.

"We wish to partake in the potential of Kazakhstan," Douglas Colkin, enterprise Oil Europe Area Manager, told the news briefing. "It gives us an entry point to Kazakhstan, from which we hope to build," he added.
Foreigners have so far invested over $2 billion in Kazakhstan's oil and gas sector out of a total of over $3.5 billion of direct investment in the country's economy.
Kazakhstan plans to become the world's sixth oil producer with 170 million tonnes a year by 2010, boosting output from some 27 million tonnes this year.
